assessment_metadata.title: Complete AWS to Azure Knowledge Assessment
assessment_metadata.description: Comprehensive evaluation covering all major service categories

questions.question: Which Azure VM series is most similar to AWS t3 instances (burstable performance)?

options.explanation: D series are general purpose but not burstable like t3 instances.
B series VMs are burstable performance instances, similar to AWS t3 instances with baseline and burst capabilities.
F series are compute-optimized, similar to AWS c5 instances.
M series are memory-optimized, similar to AWS r5 instances.

questions.question: Which Azure Blob Storage access tier is equivalent to S3 Standard-IA?

options.explanation: Hot tier is for frequently accessed data, equivalent to S3 Standard.
Cool tier is for infrequently accessed data with lower storage costs and higher access costs, similar to S3 Standard-IA.
Archive tier is for rarely accessed data, similar to S3 Glacier.
Premium tier is for high-performance scenarios, not equivalent to S3-IA.

questions.question: What is a key advantage of Azure Managed Disks over AWS EBS?

options.explanation: Pricing is competitive but not necessarily lower in all cases.
Azure Managed Disks have encryption at rest enabled by default, while EBS requires explicit enablement.
Both platforms offer similar high-IOPS options.
Both platforms offer incremental snapshots with similar performance characteristics.

questions.question: What's a key difference between AWS Security Groups and Azure Network Security Groups?

options.text: NSGs can be applied to subnets, Security Groups cannot
options.explanation: NSGs can be applied to both network interfaces and subnets, while Security Groups only apply to instances.

options.text: Security Groups support more protocols than NSGs
options.explanation: Both support similar protocol sets.
NSGs support both inbound and outbound rules.
NSGs require priority numbers, not Security Groups.

questions.question: How does Azure VNet peering differ from AWS VPC peering?

options.text: Azure VNet peering is always free
options.explanation: Azure VNet peering has data transfer charges.

options.text: Azure supports global VNet peering across regions
options.explanation: Azure VNet peering works across regions and uses the Azure backbone network, while VPC peering is region-specific.
Both platforms don't support transitive routing through peering by default.

options.text: Azure requires VPN gateways for peering
options.explanation: VNet peering doesn't require gateways, similar to VPC peering.

questions.question: What's the maximum execution timeout for Azure Functions on the Consumption plan?

options.explanation: Azure Functions on Consumption plan have a default 5-minute timeout (configurable up to 10 minutes).
15 minutes is the AWS Lambda maximum timeout.
30 minutes is available on Premium and App Service plans, not Consumption.
1 hour timeouts are not available on any Azure Functions plan.

questions.question: How do Azure Functions HTTP triggers compare to AWS API Gateway + Lambda?

options.text: Azure Functions require a separate API Gateway service
options.explanation: Azure Functions can handle HTTP requests directly without a separate API Gateway.

options.text: HTTP triggers are built into Azure Functions
options.explanation: Azure Functions can be triggered directly by HTTP requests without needing a separate API Gateway service.

options.text: Azure doesn't support custom domains for functions
options.explanation: Azure Functions support custom domains through Function Apps.

options.text: Azure has worse cold start performance
options.explanation: Cold start performance is similar, and Azure Premium plans eliminate cold starts.

questions.question: What's a key advantage of Azure Cosmos DB over AWS DynamoDB?

options.explanation: Cosmos DB is generally more expensive than DynamoDB.
Cosmos DB offers 5 consistency levels (Strong, Bounded Staleness, Session, Consistent Prefix, Eventual) vs DynamoDB's 2 (Strong, Eventual).
Both databases offer similar performance characteristics.
Both have similar item size limitations.

questions.question: What's the Azure equivalent of RDS Multi-AZ deployments?

options.explanation: Read replicas are for scaling read workloads, not high availability.
Zone-redundant configuration in Azure SQL Database provides high availability across availability zones, similar to RDS Multi-AZ.
Backup retention is about data protection, not high availability.
Connection pooling is about performance optimization, not availability.

questions.question: In Azure RBAC, what scope level is equivalent to AWS account-level permissions?

options.explanation: Management Groups can contain multiple subscriptions.
Azure Subscription scope is equivalent to AWS account-level permissions.
Resource Groups are containers within a subscription.
Resource scope is the most granular level.

questions.question: What type of Azure Managed Identity is equivalent to an IAM role for EC2 instances?

options.explanation: User-assigned identities are shared across resources.
System-assigned managed identity is tied to a specific resource, similar to IAM roles for EC2.
Service principals are for applications, not compute resources.
Azure AD groups are for user management, not resource identity.

questions.question: What Azure service is equivalent to CloudWatch Logs?

options.explanation: Log Analytics workspace is the equivalent of CloudWatch Logs for storing and querying log data.
Application Insights is more specific to application performance monitoring.
Azure Metrics is for numeric metrics, not log data.
Event Hub is for real-time event streaming, not log storage.

questions.question: What's the main difference between AWS ECS and Azure Container Instances?

options.explanation: ACI is for simple container hosting without orchestration, while ECS provides orchestration capabilities.
Pricing models differ but aren't necessarily more expensive.
ACI supports both Linux and Windows containers.
ACI is serverless and doesn't require VM management.

questions.question: What's included in the managed service offering of AKS vs EKS?

options.explanation: Azure doesn't charge for the Kubernetes master nodes in AKS, while AWS charges for the EKS control plane.
Both services require you to manage worker nodes separately.

questions.question: What's a key advantage of Azure DevOps over AWS CodePipeline?

options.explanation: Azure DevOps includes integrated project management, work item tracking, and agile planning tools.

questions.question: What is the key difference between AWS SQS Standard queues and Azure Service Bus Queues?

options.explanation: Azure Service Bus Queues guarantee FIFO ordering by default, while SQS Standard queues don't guarantee order.
Both can handle high throughput, though SQS Standard may have slightly higher limits.
Pricing varies by usage patterns and regions.
Service Bus supports transactions, SQS Standard does not.

questions.question: When migrating from AWS SNS to Azure, which scenario would require Event Grid instead of Service Bus Topics?

options.text: Publishing custom application events with schema registry
options.explanation: Event Grid is designed for event-driven architectures with custom events and built-in schema support.
Service Bus Topics would be sufficient for basic pub/sub patterns.
Service Bus would be better for high-volume messaging scenarios.
Both could work, but this doesn't specifically require Event Grid.

questions.question: How do you achieve message grouping in Azure Service Bus equivalent to SQS FIFO MessageGroupId?

options.explanation: SessionId in Service Bus provides the same message grouping functionality as MessageGroupId in SQS FIFO.
PartitionKey is used for load distribution, not message grouping.
Custom properties won't provide the built-in grouping behavior.

questions.question: What is the equivalent of DynamoDB's partition key and sort key in Cosmos DB?

options.explanation: Cosmos DB uses partition key for distribution and id as unique identifier within partition, similar to DynamoDB's key structure.
Container name is not equivalent to partition key.
These are higher-level organizational concepts.
This doesn't reflect Cosmos DB's actual structure.

questions.question: How does Cosmos DB Change Feed differ from DynamoDB Streams?

options.text: Change Feed provides ordered events per partition key
options.explanation: Cosmos DB Change Feed maintains order per logical partition, similar to DynamoDB Streams per shard.
Change Feed doesn't capture delete operations by default.
Both have similar near real-time latency characteristics.
Change Feed is included with Cosmos DB containers.

questions.question: When migrating DynamoDB Global Secondary Indexes to Cosmos DB, what's the key consideration?

options.explanation: Cosmos DB indexes consume RUs for maintenance, unlike DynamoDB GSI which has separate capacity.

options.text: Maximum number of indexes per container
options.explanation: Cosmos DB supports many more index paths than DynamoDB GSI limits.
Both systems handle cross-partition queries similarly.
Cosmos DB indexes are maintained automatically and continuously.

questions.question: What's the main architectural difference between AWS KMS and Azure Key Vault?

options.text: Key Vault stores keys, secrets, and certificates in one service
options.explanation: Key Vault is a unified service for keys, secrets, and certificates, while AWS has separate services (KMS, Secrets Manager, Certificate Manager).
Both services offer similar performance characteristics.

options.text: Key Vault requires HSM for all operations
options.explanation: Key Vault offers both software and HSM-protected keys.
KMS is regional; Key Vault can replicate across regions.

questions.question: When implementing customer-managed keys in Azure, what's equivalent to KMS key policies?

options.text: Key Vault Access Policies combined with RBAC
options.explanation: Azure uses a combination of Key Vault access policies and RBAC to control key access, similar to KMS key policies.

Tags and policies are governance features, not access control mechanisms.

options.text: Key Vault requires certificate authority integration setup
options.explanation: Key Vault requires explicit integration with certificate authorities, while ACM has built-in Let's Encrypt integration.

options.text: Key Vault certificates are more expensive
options.explanation: Cost structures differ but aren't necessarily more expensive.

options.text: Key Vault doesn't support wildcard certificates
options.explanation: Key Vault supports wildcard certificates.

options.text: Key Vault requires manual certificate renewal
options.explanation: Key Vault supports automatic certificate renewal when properly configured.

questions.question: What's the equivalent of EventBridge custom event buses in Azure Event Grid?

options.explanation: Cosmos DB offers last-write-wins, custom, and async conflict resolution policies, while DynamoDB uses last-write-wins only.

options.text: Cosmos DB requires manual conflict resolution
options.explanation: Cosmos DB can handle conflicts automatically based on configured policies.
